newsitem.title: CHINA: China to mark Hong Kong's return with video game.
newsitem.headline: China to mark Hong Kong's return with video game.

text.p: China is calling for more home-grown computer games to inspire patriotism among the young and counter a flood of politically incorrect foreign video games, the Xinhua news agency said on Thursday.

One game about the 1839-42 Opium War, which saw British forces humiliate a backward imperial China by wresting away the territory of Hong Kong, would be released when Beijing resumes control over the colony on July 1 this year, it said.

"Though China lost the war in history, players of the games can... gain a better understanding of... the impact of the war on the development of modern China, thereby inspiring patriotism for modern-day China," Xinhua said.

Foreign video games had captured 98 percent of the Chinese market and 70 percent of such imported games "advocate violence, terrorism or greed", Xinhua said, quoting a survey conducted by Qinghua University.
"Around five percent contain pornographic material, and three percent promote Nazism and militarism," the agency quoted the survey as saying.
Qinghua invested 2.0 million yuan ($240,000) in the first half of 1996 in developing video games that could instill patriotism in their young players, the agency said.
Another game was based on the experiences of Chinese pilots who shot down more than 300 U.S. fighter planes in the 1951-53 Korean War, Xinhua said.
"Such games have long been overlooked as an educational tool that could promote cultural and ethical progress," Xinhua quoted Tian Yong, president of a Beijing secondary school, as saying.
"It is impossible to prevent them (students) from playing video games," Tian said. "The best thing we can do is provide them with good games."
China's communist rulers have increasingly sought to use patriotism to replace fading Marxist values that have been eroded by nearly two decades of market-oriented economic reforms.
